title: Stage set for windsurfing worlds
text:
Stage set for windsurfing worlds Windsurfers practice at the Musannah Sports City on Sunday By Ashok Purohit October 19, 2015 
Nearly two years after the successful hosting of the Laser worlds at the Musannah Sports City, Oman has welcomed 140 top-class windsurfers from 42 countries to compete in the 2015 RS:X World Windsurfing Championships, which was officially inaugurated on Sunday evening. 
A total of 82 men and 58 women, including Olympic and world champions, are in fray for the top honours with races scheduled to be held from Monday to Saturday. 
L-R: Carlo Dalla Vedova, the president of the RS:X class, David Graham, the CEO of Oman Sail, and Rashid al Kindi, the head of the organising committee for the event, speak to the media on Sunday 
David Graham, the CEO of Oman Sail, said, “This year marks the tenth anniversary for the RS:X class, and to be chosen to host the world championships is an incredible honour for the sultanate and for Oman Sail.” 
He added, “The championship also assumes importance as it is the final major event for the windsurfers ahead of the 2016 Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil next August. 
“This world championship serves as qualifiers for the some of the nations and many countries are using this event to finalise their representatives for Rio de Janeiro.” 
Rashid al Kindi, the head of the organising committee, said, “Three races will be held per day and the ranking of the first two days will be crucial as the fleet will be split into gold and silver batches based on the first two day’s performances. The final day on October 24 will be the medal round and the races will carry double points.” 
Waleed recovering Oman’s only hopeful for the big event, Waleed al Kindi, had been ruled out due to a back injury. 
However, Graham said that ‘his recovery is on track and Waleed will be trying for a spot during a qualifier in Abu Dhabi, UAE next March’. 
The Oman Sail chief said, “Our goal is to have Waleed achieve qualification for the Olympics based on merit and we are hopeful about it. We will wait till the March regatta before taking a decision to seek a wild card for Rio.” 
Allround benefits Graham also spoke about the tourism benefits from hosting the worlds and he said the media coverage across the globe will boost the sultanate’s image as a top sailing destination. 
“There will be a significant impact of this event. Even after the conclusion, I am sure that the sailors and their parents and also the officials will carry good memories of Oman,” he said. 
Graham said that ‘hosting of such high-profile events have far-reaching impact and is fully-aligned with our vision, which extends beyond sport’. 
“The event has been managed predominantly by Omanis, be it the bidding committee, race management or the logistics teams. We are proud of them as we look forward for the successful hosting of another world championship,” said Graham. Similar content
